nodes.name: resource inefficiency in AI storage systems
aliases: inefficient memory utilisation in AI models
storage resource wastage in machine learning
nodes.description: Over-allocation or sub-optimal use of memory and parameter storage in AI systems can raise operational costs, energy use, and carbon footprint, creating secondary safety and sustainability concerns.
nodes.node_rationale: Implicitly relevant because the article centres on how many states a storage device can represent; AI systems have analogous storage constraints (Opening paragraph on storing a lot of data).

nodes.name: integer-only digit interpretation limiting storage sharing in AI systems
aliases: misallocation of memory units due to whole-digit assumption
nodes.description: If engineers assume that storage units must be allocated in whole-digit (whole-state) blocks, opportunities for finer-grained sharing are lost, directly causing inefficiency.
nodes.node_rationale: Derived from discussion that splitting a 10-digit among two people using only integer messages wastes capacity ("fair split" paragraphs).

nodes.name: probabilistic digit-sharing interpretation enabling fractional capacity in storage systems
nodes.description: Viewing a digit as a random resource to which an agent has some probability of access (e.g., 50 % of a 10-digit) allows non-integer effective digits and unlocks additional capacity.
nodes.node_rationale: Articulated when the author explains that a 3.16-digit equals a 50 % chance of a 10-digit (Section starting “You know what storage medium is worth exactly 50¢?”).

nodes.name: shared storage design based on fractional digit access probabilities in AI contexts
nodes.description: Because fractional digits arise naturally from probabilistic sharing, a design that intentionally allocates storage units probabilistically can mitigate inefficiency.
nodes.node_rationale: Follows directly from theoretical insight—if fractional use is possible, design should exploit it (same section on probabilistic digit wheels).

nodes.name: geometric mean-based fractional-digit allocation algorithm for AI memory management
nodes.description: Implementation mechanism that assigns each process a probability of accessing a storage block such that the geometric mean of capacities matches required fractional digits (e.g., √n per half-digit).
nodes.node_rationale: Based on calculations showing the average capacity equals the geometric mean (paragraphs introducing geometric mean of 1 and 10).

nodes.name: mathematical demonstration of sqrt rule improving average storage efficiency
nodes.description: Formal derivation that half-ownership of an n-digit yields √n expected states, confirming that probabilistic allocation can double effective storage density compared with integer splits.
nodes.node_rationale: Provided in sections linking two n-digits to n² states and arguing that half an n-digit equals a √n-digit.

nodes.name: design AI memory architecture with probabilistic fractional-digit sharing to maximise storage efficiency
aliases: apply sqrt-rule storage sharing in AI models
nodes.description: During model design, allocate certain memory blocks or parameter groups via probabilistic access schedules so that multiple processes or sub-models share storage, achieving an effective capacity equal to the geometric mean of full ownership and no ownership.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Applies at model-design time when deciding memory layout and sharing strategy (implied by overall discussion on how to split storage before use).
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Purely theoretical; based on mathematical exposition without empirical systems testing (entire article is theoretical).
nodes.node_rationale: Represents actionable step derived from paper—use probabilistic allocation to mitigate inefficiency.
